#Text=CHAPTER V
#Text=FOR the next two hours , Thorpe 's thoughts were almost wholly occupied with various phases of the large subject of domestic service .
#Text=He seemed suddenly to have been transported to some region populated exclusively by clean-shaven men in brown livery .

#Text=One of these was holding a spirited horse outside the station , and when Lord Plowden had taken the reins , and Thorpe had gathered the rugs about his knees and feet , this menial silently associated himself with the young man who had accompanied them from town , on the back seat of the trap .
#Text=With these people so close behind him , Thorpe felt that any intimate conversation was out of the question .

#Text=Indeed , talk of any sort was not invited ; the big horse burst forth with high , sprawling strides upon a career through the twilight , once the main road was reached , which it taxed all Plowden 's energies to regulate .

#Text=He kept up a continual murmuring monologue to the animal -- “So -- so -- quiet , my pet , -- sosoeasy , my beauty -- -so -- so” -- and his wrists and gloved hands were visibly under a tremendous tension of strain , as they held their own against the rigid arched neck and mouth of steel .
#Text=Thorpe kept a grip on the side of the trap , and had only a modified pleasure in the drive .
#Text=The road along which they sped seemed , in the gathering dusk , uncomfortably narrow , and he speculated a good deal as to how frightened the two mutes behind him must be .
#Text=But silence was such a law of their life that , though he strained his ears , he could not so much as hear them sigh or gasp .

#Text=It seemed but a very few minutes before they turned off , with but the most fleeting diminution of pace , upon a private road , which speedily developed into an avenue of trees , quite dark and apparently narrower than ever .
#Text=Down this

#Text=they raced precipitately , and then , coming out all at once upon an open space , swung smartly round the crescent of a gravel road , and halted before what seemed to be the door of a greenhouse .

#Text=Thorpe , as he stood up in the trap , got an uncertain , general idea of a low , pale-coloured mansion in the background , with lights showing behind curtains in several widely separated windows ; what he had taken to be a conservatory revealed itself now to be a glass gallery , built along the front of the central portion of this house .
#Text=A profusion of hospitable lights -- tall wax-candles in brackets among the vines against the trellised wall -- gave to this outlying entrance what the stranger felt to be a delightful effect .
#Text=Its smooth tiled floor , comfortably bestrewn with rugs , was on a level with the path outside .
#Text=There were low easy-chairs here , and a little wicker table bearing books and a lady 's work-basket .
#Text=Further on , giant chrysanthemum blooms were massed beneath the clusters of pale plumbago-flowers on the trellis .

#Text=Directly in front , across the dozen feet of this glazed vestibule , the broad doorway of the house proper stood open -- with warm lights glowing richly upon dark woods in the luxurious obscurity within .
#Text=What Thorpe noted most of all , however , was the servants who seemed to swarm everywhere .
#Text=The two who had alighted from the trap had contrived somehow mysteriously to multiply themselves in the darkness .

#Text=All at once there were a number of young men -- at the horse 's head , at the back and sides of the trap , at the first doorway , and the second , and beyond -- each presenting such a smooth-faced , pallid , brown-clad replica of all the others that Thorpe knew he should never be able to tell them apart .
#Text=Lord Plowden paused for a moment under the candle-light to look at his watch .
#Text=“ We did it in a bit over eight minutes , ” he remarked , with obvious satisfaction .
#Text=“ With four people and heavy roads that 's not so bad -- not so bad .
#Text=But come inside . ”
#Text=They moved forward through the wide doorway into an apartment the like of which Thorpe had not seen before .
#Text=It was a large , square room , with a big staircase at the end , which separated and went off to right and left , half-way up its visible course .
#Text=Its floor was of inlaid woods , old and uneven from long use , and carpeted here and there by the skins of tigers and leopards .

#Text=There were many other suggestions of the chase about the room : riding boots , whips , spurs , and some stands of archaic weapons caught the eye at various points ; the heads of foxes and deer peeped out on the blackened panels of the walls , from among clusters of hooks crowded with coats , hats , and mackintoshes .
#Text=At the right , where a fire glowed and blazed under a huge open chimney-place , there were low chairs and divans drawn up to mark off a space for orderly domestic occupation .

#Text=The irregularity of every thing outside -- the great table in the centre of the hall strewn with an incongruous litter of caps , books , flasks , newspapers , gloves , tobacco-pouches ; the shoes , slippers , and leggings scattered under the benches at the sides --
#Text=all this self-renewing disorder of a careless household struck Thorpe with a profound surprise .
#Text=It was like nothing so much as a Mexican ranch -- and to find it in the ancestral home of an English nobleman , filled to overflowing with servants , amazed him .
#Text=The glances that he cast about him , however , were impassive enough .
#Text=His mind was charged with the ceaseless responsibility of being astonished at nothing .
#Text=A man took his hat , and helped him off with his coat .
#Text=Another moved toward the staircase with his two bags .
